aircraft. 
Participants noted that an unrealistically high traffic level was simulated to maximize the use of 
the Path Stretch tool in conjunction with RTA. MITRE staff confirmed that excessive traffic xxii levels were used to push the limits of Sector 93 arrival management. Pilot Feedback4.8
There were two pilots controlling one flight each with the FMS simulator and two pseudo pilots 
each controlling multiple RTA flights in each of the HITL simulation runs. Q1 and Q2 of the 
pilot survey were only applicable to the former. The rest, Q3 to Q5, were applicable to all the 
pilots. Averaged scores for the FMS simulator and pseudo pilots are reported in Figure 15 and 
Figure 16, respectively. A high level of agreement to a question indicates that the survey 
participant found the concept useful or operationally acceptable. Strongly Disagree Disagree Neutral Agree Strongly Agree Average Likert Scale FMS Pilot Response Figure 15. Average FMS Pilot Scores As can be seen in Figure 15,the FMS FAA Certified ATPL pilots rated Q1 (the straightforward 
ability to program the FMS for an en route RTA for TBFM extended metering) the highest 
possible score. They also rated high Q2 and Q3, related to the straightforward monitoring of RTA 
operation, both with a score of 4. Q4 (the assessment of the workload necessary to operate RTAs 
for TBFM extended metering versus current practice) scored the lowest. Finally, they more than 
agreed with the assessment of the usefulness of RTA operation in Q5. xxiii Strongly Disagree Disagree Neutral Agree Strongly Agree Average Likert Scale Pseudo Pilot Response Figure 16. Average Pseudo Pilot Scores Figure 16 shows that the pseudo pilots scored Q3, Q4, and Q5 the same as the FMS pilots. 
Reiterating the usefulness of RTAs for TBFM extended metering operations. Pilots Qualitative Results4.9
Pilots remarks and comments were collected in the final part of the survey. A summary of the 
remarks from the FMS pilots are presented below. Reported that he/she did not monitor the speed changes that the FMS was using to 
achieve the STA with the RTA function. He/she trusted the automation. Reported that using the RTA instead of a speed requires slightly more manipulation 
on the FMS. Reported that a six-digit number for the STA was hard to hear, commenting that if the 
clearance was unexpected, this format could be confusing for pilots. Also 
acknowledged that this could be a personal issue and that could be mitigated once the 
RTAs become more commonly used. xxiv Summary and Conclusions5
The part-task HITL evaluation presented in this paper was focused on the use of integrated Path 
Stretch and RTA clearances in the cruise extended metering environment. The low RTA 
cancellation rate and the positive feedback from the controller and pilot questionnaires collected 
showed the operational feasibility of the TBM-RTA ConOps. Moreover, the higher delivery 
accuracy at the meter point achieved by the RTA flights demonstrated that, at least in cruise, the 
functionality can provide a benefit. Lastly, the relatively low speed adjustments implemented by 
the FMS RTA to achieve the higher delivery accuracy allowed the controllers to monitor RTA 
flights with several minor improvements to the information already provided by the displays that 
they currently use. 
The HITL simulation operational scenarios were designed to put excess stress on the extended 
metering operation to test the functional integration of the Path Stretch, RTA, and GIM-S meet-
time advisories. As a result, controllers were managing traffic that was workload-intensive at 
times. This caused the controller in sector 93 to occasionally intervene and issue speed and/or 
vector clearances to flights before handing off to sector 39. Controllers recognized that these 
speeds and/or vectors were necessary because of the higher than normal traffic represented in the 
simulation. 
Another finding related to the higher than normal traffic during the evaluation is that, in a dense 
traffic environment, even if aircraft meet their STA perfectly, there could be some separation 
issues after crossing the meter point. For example, if consecutive aircraft cross the meter point at 
different speeds, even if perfectly separated at the meter point meeting their STA, post-crossing 
spacing can decrease to levels that are uncomfortable to the controllers. Therefore, the necessity 
to apply speed control to several aircraft by the receiving controller in sector 39 was observed 
occasionally during the HITL simulation. 6 xxv Next Steps7
While the HITL simulation showed that the TBM-RTA concept is operationally feasible, 
additional studies need to be conducted to assess the benefits of using RTA for en route extended 
metering versus the use of GIM-S advisories. A key focus of future studies will be whether the 
higher delivery accuracy achieved by RTA flights translates into benefits such as increased 
throughput or reduced delays. 
The HITL simulation also demonstrated the feasibility of the ConOps in extended metering in en 
route cruise, but questions remain about the feasibility during the en route descent phase for 
metering to the TRACON. Greater RTA performance uncertainty is expected when aircraft 
altitude changes occur, and the results of this HITL simulation cannot be directly extended to that 
type of operation. Managing RTA flights that are metering and transitioning across multiple 
sectors should also be explored, as this was not studied in this HITL simulation. 
Another important issue that needs to be validated is the use of more realistic wind forecast errors 
between the TBFM system and the FMS. MITRE expects the benefits of RTA over GIM-S to be 
higher in actual operations where the wind prediction accuracy is lower than what was modeled 
for the evaluation.
A key next step is to study a more realistic depiction of arrival traffic flows. The HITL simulation 
conducted included higher than normal traffic levels operating in an arrival flow corridor which 
created some unexpected challenges, previously described. It would be desirable to simulate 
traffic over a four cornerpost environment to allow TBFM to provide more balanced traffic 
demand loading via the schedule. xxvi Acknowledgments8
MITRE CAASD would like to express our thanks to Guillermo Sotelo, Kerry Capes, and Rob 
Hunt from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) who provided valuable input to help guide 
this research. The authors would also like to express our thanks to the other MITRE staff who 
supported this research on our project team: Alain Oswald, Clark Britan, Mahesh Balakrishna, 
Bill Bateman, Daniel Kirk and Elly Smith. xxvii References9
